description.text: If the company details or structure have changed contact us on {telephone_number_link} or email {email_link}

list: Data should relate to all sites in the UK. This includes England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
We will treat your information securely and confidentially.

This survey is refreshed every two weeks. To avoid losing data and to help us provide real-time information please submit by the return by date, or at the latest before the next fortnightly survey goes live.
On average it takes 5 minutes to complete this survey once you have collected the information.
You can save a copy of your answers at the end of this questionnaire using the ’Download as PDF’ button.

contents.description: Please complete this survey even if you are a sole trader and it does not seem relevant to your business. All returns are important, as it allows decision-makers to understand how businesses of all sizes are performing in the current climate.
Thank you for participating in this important survey.
View the questions before you start the survey (this link opens in a new tab)
This survey has the following sections:
This section asks for general information on your business’s trading status.
This section asks for information about:
This section asks for information about:
This section asks for information about CE (Conformity with European health, safety, and environment) and UKCA markings.

The CE marking is mandatory for most products sold within the European Economic Area (EEA). The CE marking indicates that a product has been manufactured in compliance with the EU’s health, safety, performance and environmental requirements.

The UKCA (UK Conformity Assessed) marking is the UK’s own product marking for placing most goods on the market in Great Britain (GB). It is used to demonstrate conformity with the legal requirements in GB and can currently be applied instead of, or in addition to, the CE marking for a range of products for the GB market.
This section asks for information about:

list: purchase of goods or services from other UK nations
sale of goods or services from other UK nations
sending goods from GB to Northern Ireland, as well as from Northern Ireland to GB, and any related challenges

contents.description: This section asks for information about:

list: the availability of materials, goods and services within the EU
intentions to open any new branches or subsidiaries in the EU
your business’s use of UK Freeports

contents.description: This section asks for information about your business’s use of collective redundancies.

The data from this survey is used widely to enable rapid response, and inform policy decisions about issues impacting UK businesses and the economy. This includes topics relating to business resilience, financial performance, trade and your workforce.
View the latest publication produced from this survey (this link opens in a new tab)
This section asks for general information on your business’s trading status.

title.text: Which of the following statements best describes {ru_name}’s trading status?

description:
You can interpret ’trading’ as ’operating’.

Only select ’paused trading’ if all trading or operations have temporarily stopped.

options.label: Currently partially trading
options.description: For example, trading with reduced hours or staff numbers

options.label: Paused trading but intends to restart in the next two weeks
Paused trading and does not intend to restart in the next two weeks

contents.description: This section asks for information about:

title.text: Has {ru_name} exported goods or services in the last 12 months?

contents.description: Include exporting services from your businesses in the UK to an individual or business located outside of the UK
This refers to skills and services that are provided by people and are ’intangible’.
For example, your business may provide a service, such as legal or financial services, to a non-UK business.

options.label: Business has not exported goods or services in the last 12 months

question.title: Where has your business exported goods or services to in the last three months?

options.label: Not exported in the last three months

blocks.page_title: Destination of exported goods or services

question.title: Has your business had any extra costs directly related to changes in export regulations due to the end of the EU transition period?

contents.description: Include customs and compliance with regulations
Exclude transport costs

definitions.title: What we mean by ’end of the EU transition period’

contents.description: This refers to the transition period after the United Kingdom left the European Union. The transition period ended on 31 December 2020.

options.label: Costs increased but are now stable
Costs increased and are still increasing
Costs were stable but are now increasing
No cost increases experienced at any point

question.title: How did your business’s exporting in December 2024 compare with the same calendar month last year?
How did your business’s cost of exporting in December 2024 compare with the same calendar month last year?
How did the time spent on exporting in December 2024 compare with the same calendar month last year?
Which of the following support options has your business benefitted from, to help with exporting challenges?

options.label: Finding new overseas contacts or customers
Information on exporting
options.description: For example, changes to requirements following the end of the EU transition period

question.title: Does your business currently meet the rules of origin to access preferential tariffs on exports?

contents.description: This refers to zero or lower tariffs.

options.label: All exports meet the rules of origin to access preferential tariffs
Some exports meet the rules of origin to access preferential tariffs
Exports do not meet the rules of origin to access preferential tariffs
Not applicable
options.description: For example, the partner country does not change tariffs

guidance.show_guidance: What we mean by ’rules of origin’ on exports
guidance.hide_guidance: What we mean by ’rules of origin’ on exports

contents.description: This refers to the criteria used to determine where a product was made. They exist in all Free Trade Agreements to ensure only goods made in countries that are part of the agreement can benefit from lower tariffs.
View further information about rules of origin on the gov.uk website (this link opens in a new tab)

question.title: Why does your business not currently meet the rules of origin to access preferential tariffs on exports?

definitions.title: What we mean by ’preferential’ tariffs on exports

contents.description: This refers to zero or lower tariffs.

options.label: Exports cannot meet rules of origin requirements
options.description: For example, goods do not have enough originating content

options.label: Administrative costs of rules of origin are too high or burdensome
Lack of knowledge
options.description: For example, business was not aware of preferential tariff or how to access it

options.label: Lack of understanding, staffing or expertise
options.description: For example, business was aware of preferential tariff, but was not aware of how to comply with rules of origin

guidance.show_guidance: What we mean by ’rules of origin’ on exports
guidance.hide_guidance: What we mean by ’rules of origin’ on exports

contents.description: This refers to the criteria used to determine where a product was made. They exist in all Free Trade Agreements to ensure only goods made in countries that are part of the agreement can benefit from lower tariffs.
View further information about rules of origin on the gov.uk website (this link opens in a new tab)

contents.description: This section asks for information about CE (Conformity with European health, safety, and environment) and UKCA markings.

The CE marking is mandatory for most products sold within the European Economic Area (EEA). The CE marking indicates that a product has been manufactured in compliance with the EU’s health, safety, performance and environmental requirements.

The UKCA (UK Conformity Assessed) marking is the UK’s own product marking for placing most goods on the market in Great Britain (GB). It is used to demonstrate conformity with the legal requirements in GB and can currently be applied instead of, or in addition to, the CE marking for a range of products for the GB market.

title.text: Does {ru_name} manufacture, import or distribute products for the GB market that use a CE or UKCA marking?

contents.description: Exclude products for outside of the GB market

definitions.title: What we mean by ’CE’ and ’UKCA’ markings

contents.description:
The CE marking is mandatory for most products sold within the European Economic Area (EEA). The CE marking indicates that a product has been manufactured in compliance with the EU’s health, safety, performance and environmental requirements.

The UKCA (UK Conformity Assessed) marking is the UK’s own product marking for placing most goods on the market in Great Britain (GB). It is used to demonstrate conformity with the legal requirements in GB and can currently be applied instead of, or in addition to, the CE marking for a range of products for the GB market.

options.label: Yes, the business manufactures products that need a CE or UKCA marking
Yes, the business imports products that need a CE or UKCA marking
Yes, the business distributes products that need a CE or UKCA marking
No, the business does not manufacture, import or distribute products that need a CE or UKCA marking

blocks.page_title: Products that require CE or UKCA marking

question.title: Approximately, what proportion of the products your business manufactures, imports or distributes for the GB market currently use the UKCA marking instead of, or in addition to, the CE marking?

definitions.title: What we mean by ’proportion of the products’

contents.description: This refers to the number of UKCA or CE marked products that the business manufacture, import, or distribute for the GB market overall.

options.label: Business is using UKCA marking for all products
Business is using UKCA marking for a majority of products, but not all
Business is using UKCA marking for a minority of products
Business is not using UKCA marking

blocks.page_title: How business is using a CE or UKCA marking

definitions.title: What we mean by ’proportion of the products’

contents.description: This refers to the number of UKCA or CE marked products that the business manufacture, import, or distribute for the GB market overall.

options.label: Business intends to use UKCA marking for all products in this calendar month next year
Business intends to use UKCA marking for a majority of products, but not all, in this calendar month next year
Business intends to use UKCA marking for a minority of products in this calendar month next year
Business does not intend to use UKCA marking in this calendar month next year

contents.description: This section asks for information about:

list: purchase of goods or services from other UK nations
sale of goods or services from other UK nations
sending goods from GB to Northern Ireland, as well as from Northern Ireland to GB, and any related challenges

title.text: In the last 12 months, has {ru_name} purchased goods or services from suppliers in other UK nations?

contents.description: Exclude goods or services purchased within the same UK nation

definitions.title: What we mean by ’other UK nations’

contents.description: This refers to purchasing from suppliers in a UK nation outside of the nation where the majority of your business resides. The four nations that make up the UK are England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

blocks.page_title: Purchases from suppliers in other UK nations

question.title: In the last 12 months, which of the following goods or services has your business purchased from suppliers in other UK nations?

contents.description: Exclude goods or services purchased within the same UK nation

definitions.title: What we mean by ’other UK nations’

contents.description: This refers to purchasing from suppliers in a UK nation outside of the nation where the majority of your business resides. The four nations that make up the UK are England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

options.label: Casual labour
options.description: Include the location of the supplier or their local branch, not where the labourers live

options.label: Financial services
options.description: This refers to the investment, lending and management of money and assets as well as the provision of insurance, reinsurance and pension funding activities

options.label: Finished goods
options.description: This refers to goods that have completed the manufacturing process and are ready for sale

options.label: Professional services
options.description: This refers to activities that require a high degree of training, and make specialised knowledge and skills available to users. For example, legal, consultancy, advertising or engineering services

options.label: Semi-finished or intermediate goods
options.description: This refers to goods that have been partly made or processed and require further processing to become a finished good. For example, car or machine parts

options.label: Raw materials
options.description: This refers to the basic input goods that your business requires to manufacture its products

blocks.page_title: Type of purchases from other UK nations

title.text: Does {ru_name} plan to import or export goods to or from UK Freeports in the next 12 months?

contents.description: This refers to designated zones within England and Wales, and Green Freeports in Scotland, where eligible businesses can benefit from a package of measures that include tax reliefs, simplified customs trade and investment support.

question.title: Why is your business not planning to import or export goods from UK Freeports within the next 12 months?

options.label: Application is unlikely to be processed in time
Application was rejected by HM Revenue and Customs
Business does not import or export goods to or from the UK
Business is already utilising existing customs procedures
Business is not located in a designated freeport area

contents.description: This section asks for information about your business’s use of collective redundancies.

question.title: Has your business gone through a collective redundancy consultation in the last 12 months?

definitions.title: What we mean by ’collective redundancy consultation’

contents.description: This refers to a process that must be followed if an employer is making 20 or more employees redundant within a 90-day period at a single establishment. These consultations should be carried out with a view of reaching an agreement on the proposed redundancies, although they do not need to end in agreement.
This includes options to avoid redundancies, reduce the number of employees to be made redundant, and mitigate the consequences of any dismissals.

guidance.show_guidance: Why are we asking this question?
guidance.hide_guidance: Why are we asking this question?

contents.description: Your answer provides us with a better understanding of the number of redundancies made via collective redundancy and the effectiveness of consultation at reducing redundancies.

question.title: Approximately, how many redundancies did your business make following this collective redundancy consultation process?

guidance.show_guidance: Why are we asking this question?
guidance.hide_guidance: Why are we asking this question?

contents.description: Your answer provides us with a better understanding of the number of redundancies made via collective redundancy and the effectiveness of consultation at reducing redundancies.

blocks.page_title: Redundancies made during collective redundancy process

question.title: Approximately, how many redundancies was your business considering before the collective redundancy consultation process?

guidance.show_guidance: Why are we asking this question?
guidance.hide_guidance: Why are we asking this question?

contents.description: Your answer provides us with a better understanding of the number of redundancies made via collective redundancy and the effectiveness of consultation at reducing redundancies.

blocks.page_title: Redundancies considered before collective redundancy process
